channel.title: Handheld Linux device comming out soon
channel.description:
Well I have been watching this for a while now, it is called The Pandora, and I have decided to get it once it comes out. [img]http://www.openpandora.ca/images/pand09050_logo3a.JPG[/img] the specs: - Texas Instruments OMAP3530 processor at 600MHz (officially)
- 128MB DDR-333 SDRAM
- 256MB NAND FLASH memory
- IVA2+ audio and video processor using TI's DaVinci™ technology
(430MHz C64x DSP)
- ARM® Cortex™-A8 superscalar microprocessor core
- PowerVR SGX530 (110MHz officially) OpenGL ES 2.0 compliant 3D hardware
- integrated Wifi 802.11b/g
- integrated Bluetooth 2.0 + EDR (3Mbps)
- 800x480 resolution LTPS LCD with touch screen, 4.3" widescreen, 16.7 million colors (300 cd/m2 brightness, 450:1 contrast ratio)
- Dual analog controllers with center pushbutton
- Full gamepad controls plus shoulder buttons
- Dual SDHC card slots (up to 64GB of storage)
- headphone output up to 150mW/channel into 16 ohms, 99dB SNR (up to 24 bit/48KHz)
- TV output (composite and S-Video)
- Internal microphone plus ability to connect external microphone through headset
- 43 button QWERTY and numeric keypad
- USB 2.0 OTG port (480Mb/s) with capability to charge device
- USB 2.0 HOST port (480Mb/s) capable of providing the full 500mA to attached devices (examples include USB hard drives and flash memory sticks)
- externally accessible UART for hardware hacking and debugging
- un-brickable design with integrated boot loader for safe code experimentation
- Runs on the Linux operating system (2.6.x)
- Dimensions: 140x83x27mm
the planned price: $330(not including VAT)
you can get more information at [url=http://www.openpandora.org]http://www.openpandora.org[/url]
I have been paying attention to this for the last 3 months, and they seem to be progressing, but they are most likely to be pushed back on date again(as the 100 units made for the Dev's to use until most required stuff for the general user is coded/ported) which was supposed to be last month, but so far has not happened(perfecting hardware stuff, recently added BlueTooth into the project) It will have 10 hours of batter life, over 50 for Mp3 use, and so on. It seems to have much prospect in it, and of course(otherwise I would not have posted in this section) it will run a custom Linux on the NAND. they put 2 SDHC card slots on there, and you could easily get a 16GB card right now for $61 free shipping online, as 32GB cards are still very very expensive. This device will also be able to provide full USB host support power-wise while on battery, meaning, if you wanted to, you could use a USB-only powered external HDD for a while, but SD cards would last longer for the battery life.

item.title: Handheld Linux device comming out soon
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

Yeah, they are using high quality components in it. Right now it is hectic because the Chinese plant decided to no longer manufacture the Analog Nubs(the flat joysticks). There may be a slight further delay, but things seem to be running smoothly. A French Programmer(works in a processor architecture team) who’s hobby is developing emulators for the GP2X(another linux handheld, but didn’t turn out the best) and the PSP has volunteered for porting just about all the 8-bit systems into it.
It seems to be pushed back to late august or September for the public.

Read full topic

Looks quite good though.

item.source: Handheld Linux device comming out soon

item.title: Handheld Linux device comming out soon
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

It is a totally open source system, and there are already people making emulators and other stuff for it right now. It is mainly a UMPC with everything of a laptop and gaming controls put together in about a normal DS sized device. They are still working on it, but they now have MK0 motherboard pictures out that are not bent by the mailman’s lack of care.
I would get it for the laptop/UMPC abilities. But it is Jammed pack with tons of stuff. The Developers have hardly any time to post updates on their progress. Several people are excited and several Linux and portable device organizations have taken a look into it as it becomes more real each day.

I doubt that many games will come out for it specifically that are full length, it is meant for emulation game-wise mostly. PSX ISO’s are easy to get to use on a playstation emulator when it is ported(planned)

Read full topic
item.source: Handheld Linux device comming out soon
